comments.author: Eric Garrison

captions.text: Back in 2010 Mercedes-Benz showed off a car that really grabbed public attention
and that's for several reasons.
A 0-60 time of less than four seconds, striking looks

and doors that opened upwards rather
than outwards. But the problem for many
people with the SLS AMG GT

was its price. It was priced to compete with
things like the Ferrari 458

Now despite some obvious visual
similarities, this new

AMG GT is a very different prospect in
many ways.

Here are five reasons why we are very
excited about this new car.

Mercedes aims to take on cars like the
Porsche 911 and the Audi R8 - both

big-selling sports cars. The big
difference between this car and
those is the layout. The Porsche, for example, has its engine back here.
The R8, a bit further forward, is mid-engined. The Mercedes,

as you can probably tell by this really long
swooping bonnet, is front engined. However,

the power from it goes to the rear wheels
like a lot of other sports cars.

Mercedes also says that the weight
distribution is optimal as well. That it gets
47% up front and 53%

over the rear. To start off with there will be
only two versions of the GT but both of
them will use
a version this 4.0-litre biturbo V8
engine. Both of them are pretty rapid though. The entry-level version, if you can call
it that,
has got 456bhp and we'll get from 0 to 60 in
4.0 seconds. The S version, which is a slightly tuned version
of the same engine - that's this one here - has got 503 brake horsepower and gets from
0-60 in 3.8 seconds.

It's not unlikely, however, that in the
future there will be more versions of this car

as there was in the SLS AMG GT - things
like a Black edition, stuff at that - that will

boost the car in terms of performance
and other specification.
Nothing has been confirmed long along those lines just yet but watch this space.
Now one big notable change on this car

over the SLS is these doors. Instead of
opening upwards
they open in a much more conventional way and the hinges are
at the front. While that might not look quite as cool as the

gullwing versions it does mean that they
are much lighter and this has knock-on
effect on things like performance
and economy. Mercedes says the even higher powered version of this car
is capable of 30mpg. The GT part of this car's name implies that this is a Grand Tourer, or
the sort of car

you want to spend a lot of time covering
long distances in.
This interior really does back that up. It is
a fantastic place in many ways. These materials feel wonderful,
this central cockpit and the seats really hug you in

so it feels like a sporty yet luxurious
car.

There is also a huge amount of space.
There is loads of legroom for the passenger there,

but you get a vast boot in this car. At
350 litres

it is bigger than things like the Ford
Focus. Obviously

it's not the same shape so you can't get a
big suitcase and stuff but there is

enough room for soft bags so you'll be
able to go away for a long weekend
rather than just a night.
As well as being quicker, higher-power versions of this car get some real
upgrades to boost things like handling. It gets the AMG ride control system, which

means you can stiffen or soften up the
suspension.

It also gets bigger brakes, 19-inch
wheels at the front and 20-inch versions
at the back,

and an electronic differential, whereas the
standard version gets a mechanical version.
Pricing for this car starts slap-bang in Porsche 911 territory at £97,195

If you want this version - the S
version - it's
gonna cost you about £110,000

and there are, obviously, a huge range of
options you can

add on top of that as much or as little
as you wish.

This card will start heading out to its
first customers in April 2015

but in the meantime we'll be driving it
in November so keep an eye on whatcar.com
for our verdict then.

Also, there is much more
information on our website so do

take a look straight away to keep up to
date with everything to know about this
car.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz AMG GT - five reasons to be excited - What Car?
